Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Dynamics of Pneumatic Isolators in Ultra-Precision Manufacturing Machines

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ultra-precision manufacturing (UPM) machines enable the production of micro- and nano-devices that are critical for the advances in the electronics, biomedical, communications and other cutting-edge industries. As a critical step in meeting UPM machineâ€™s stringent precision requirement, they must be isolated from unwanted vibrations stemming from fast moving machines and ground motions. For this purpose, pneumatic (passive) isolators are often preferred over active systems because of their relatively low cost and energy efficiency. Recent studies have demonstrated that the performance of pneumatic isolators can be significantly improved using more sophisticated control approaches. However, those past studies did not account for the well-known inherent complex, and nonlinear, behaviors in pneumatic isolators. The aim of this award is to support fundamental research to understand the nonlinear dynamics of passively-isolated UPM machines and determine how the benefits of nonlinear dynamics can be exploited to improve the performance of pneumatic isolators. The knowledge gained will enable U.S. manufacturing industry to build cheaper, better, and faster UPM machines, advancing national prosperity and impacting efforts to secure the national defense. In a broader context, the findings can also be applied to a broader class of nonlinear mechanical and electromechanical systems. The research work will also help broaden the representation and retention of underrepresented minority (URM) in engineering fields.

The research project will be the first to conduct a nonlinear vibration analysis of pneumatic isolators to scientifically reveal whether the benefits of mode coupling observed in linear systems can be extended to nonlinear systems. To this end, a nonlinear system identification via a direct reconciliation of experimental measurements and theoretical modeling will be conducted to detect and quantify the nonlinear stiffness and nonlinear damping of pneumatic isolators. A thorough theoretical analysis will then be carried out to understand the interplay between nonlinear mode coupling, stability, and bifurcation in pneumatic isolated UPM machines. Optimal control theory will be used to determine the optimum design parameters, which will then serve as guidelines for improving the design of pneumatic isolators. Rigorous physical experimentation will be performed to guide and validate the theoretical findings. The outcome of the researched work will lead to new insights on how to exploit nonlinear dynamic phenomena for improving the performance of pneumatic isolators. The PI will continue to focus on the participation from underrepresented groups though connections to the National Society of Black Engineers and other STEM-related activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:  
Ultra-precision manufacturing (UPM) machines enable the production of micro and nano devices that drive advances in electronics, biomedical, communications, and other cutting-edge industries. To meet the stringent precision requirements of UPM machines, they must be isolated from unwanted vibrations caused by fast-moving machines and ground motions. Pneumatic (passive) isolators are often preferred over active systems due to their lower cost and energy efficiency. Recent studies have demonstrated that the performance of pneumatic isolators can be significantly improved through mode coupling. However, these studies did not account for the inherent nonlinearities in pneumatic isolators. This award has supported a fundamental scientific investigation to understand the nonlinear dynamics of UPM machines with pneumatic isolators. The investigation aims to determine how system nonlinearities can be exploited to enhance the performance of pneumatic isolators. The knowledge gained from this research can enable the U.S. manufacturing industry to improve the performance of UPM machines by effectively isolating them from surrounding vibrations, thereby contributing to the advancement and viability of precision manufacturing processes.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project provided a thorough understanding of nonlinear pneumatic isolators in UPM machines through comprehensive nonlinear vibration analysis, including system identification, theoretical analysis, and experimental validation. By using the method of multiple scales, the nonlinear dynamics of pneumatic isolators were analyzed, focusing on primary and secondary resonance. Parametric analysis through the mode coupling parameter revealed supercritical, subcritical, and s-shaped bifurcations. Experimental analyses were carried out on the prototype of UPM with pneumatic isolators to develop empirical models for nonlinear stiffness and damping, depicting the softening nonlinearity in both stiffness and damping. Further analysis identified the critical impact of these nonlinearities and isolator location, which can lead to subcritical Hopf bifurcation. Numerical optimization revealed detrimental nonlinear mode coupling, refuting previous claims of its benefits. By characterizing these nonlinear properties and their effects on mode coupling, stability, and bifurcation, the research will provide new insights and practical guidelines for designing more efficient vibration isolation systems in UPM, enhancing accuracy, productivity, and cost-efficiency. Three international peer-reviewed journal papers and two peer-reviewed conference papers have been produced from this research.

 

Broder Impacts: 

The proposed research provides new insights into the nonlinear dynamics of pneumatic isolators, leading to more efficient and cost-effective vibration isolation systems for UPM machines. These findings enhance the accuracy, speed, and reliability of UPM processes and can be applied to fields such as civil infrastructure and vibration energy harvesting. The PI has successfully integrated the research findings into his graduate course ME6984: Nonlinear Vibrations and Applications at Virginia Tech, enriching the curriculum and providing students with cutting-edge knowledge and skills. This project has also provided mentorship opportunities for one Postdoc, one PhD, and one undergraduate student, fostering the next generation of researchers and engineers in the field. Additionally, the PI's outreach program aimed at recruiting underrepresented minorities into STEM fields has been running successfully. Through this program, underrepresented students are introduced to scientific research and encouraged to pursue careers in engineering, contributing to the diversity and inclusivity of the STEM workforce.

 


Last Modified: 08/18/2024
Modified by: Oumar Barry

The knowledge gained from this research can enable the U.S. manufacturing industry to improve the performance of UPM machines by effectively isolating them from surrounding vibrations, thereby contributing to the advancement and viability of precision manufacturing processes.
